Estimated base rate, recent attempts, elite discord, and ongoing insurgent pressure yield a probability somewhat above base historical frequency, but not to highly confident extremes, as regime hardening and coup-proofing are also very apparent.

Given the 1.5-month window, successful coups are low-frequency but not rare events in Africa, especially under present conditions. Aggregating all factors, I judge the probability at 28%—higher than base rates for most of modern history, but reflecting tangible short-term countermeasures and the limited window.

The absolute number of historically successful coups in any 6-week period is low, but above zero during recent upticks. Latin America, despite unrest, is unlikely to see a sudden regime change due to more robust civilian control and fewer recent military uprisings of the classic type. My best forecast, integrating heightened but plateauing coup climate in Africa, junta adaptation, short horizon, and regional contagion, is that the risk is materially above the 5% baseline but not above 20%. The chance hinges almost entirely on West African juntas (especially Mali and Burkina Faso) and—less likely—on Guinea-Bissau or Benin if political crises escalate drastically.

Guinea-Bissau's defective election could trigger a destabilizing event but the opposition is already sidelined and the security sector is under executive control. Therefore, the short time horizon (six weeks), relative absence of scheduled transitions, and current regime resilience suggest a higher-than-baseline but less-than-even risk—driven almost exclusively by the African Sahel. Neo-patrimonial regimes tend to breed institutional distrust and elite competition, while their reliance on patronage and the weakness of legitimacy make them susceptible to both internal and external shocks.
